title: Immigration enforcement officers are spotted monitoring crowds at train station near Glastonbury
body:
Immigration enforcement officers were spotted outside Castle Cary station yesterday as thousands of revellers heading to the first day of Glastonbury Festival arrived.

Photos shared on social media showed two officers leaning on a rail outside the small train station in Somerset, seemingly awaiting the arrival of festivalgoers heading down to Worthy Farm.

Griff Ferris, who was heading to the festival which will see Elton John, the Arctic Monkeys and Gun N' Roses play this weekend, said that officers told members of the public they were monitoring crowds for 'adverse reactions'.

These reactions would then be used as grounds to pull people over and question them, it has been reported.

'It was bizarre seeing the two of them there. I asked them what they were doing, and they said they were here monitoring adverse reactions to them', Mr Ferris told the Independent.

Two immigration enforcement officers were seen waiting outside Castle Cary station as hundreds arrived for Glastonbury Festival

One festival goer Griff Ferris claimed the officers were monitoring 'adverse reactions' to them

It comes as thousands descended on Worthy Farm in Somerset for a five-day long festival

'I didn't see them check anyone, but you have to walk past them. It's just really grim. There are thousands of people coming through the station today and there's a huge queue, and as you're queueing to get your ticket checked they're there.'

Glastonbury Festival told MailOnline that it's 'not responsible for - or in any way involved - with the policing or enforcement away from the site'.

Crowds of excited music fans crammed their way into the 900-acre site yesterday, ready for five-days full of first-class music stars, as well as speeches by politcians, film screenings, threatre and circus performances.

The gates for the festival were officially opened by co-organiser Emily Eavis this morning, after attendees queued overnight to be the first in at 8am.

Glastonbury co-founder Michael Eavis, who was recently pictured in a wheelchair, sat in a red Land Rover nearby as his daughter opened the gates for the festival.

Spirits were high despite the downpours of rain and thundery storms, as groups of people dragged in crates of beer and boxes of booze ready for the long weekend.

As the rain clearer, hundreds gathered to watch the sunset above the park before seeing a magnificent firework display.

Many waking up from their tents this morning likely woke up with sore heads after partying the night away.

Yesterday thousands arrived to set up camp in Glastonbury, getting soaked by thundery storms

Spirits were high as festivalgoers enjoyed the first day of entertainment on the farm

People were seen carrying in crates and crates of booze as they battled through stormy showers

As the rain clearer, hundreds gathered to watch the sunset above the park before seeing a magnificent firework display.

Many waking up from their tents this morning likely woke up with sore heads after partying the night away.

Thousands gathered to watch the sunset above the park on the first day of Glastonbury Festival

Arctic Monkeys will top the bill on Friday night on the Pyramid Stage, which will be their third time headlining the festival having previously done so in 2007 and 2013.

Lizzo will play immediately before and has joint headline billing on the line-up poster.

However, the acts closing the Pyramid Stage throughout the festival will be all-male.

Co-organiser Ms Eavis told the BBC she aimed for gender balance and this year they had a female headline but 'she unfortunately had to pull out'.

Sir Elton John's headline slot on Sunday night is expected to draw large crowds, as it marks the end of his scheduled farewell tour dates in the UK.

Yusuf/Cat Stevens will perform during the teatime legends slot on Sunday afternoon, followed by classic rock outfit Blondie.

The veteran folk-rocker, best known for a string of albums in the 1970s, follows in the footsteps of artists such as Dolly Parton, Kylie Minogue and Diana Ross in the coveted slot.

Also on the bill across the weekend are Christine And The Queens, Lana Del Rey, Lewis Capaldi and Lil Nas X.

MailOnline has contacted the Home Office.

The context—opening the gates, speaking to the BBC about gender balance—confirms her role and identity. No other person named Emily Eavis is mentioned, and the details align with the Wikidata profile.

reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for a co‑organiser of a major music festival to speak to the BBC about programming decisions and gender balance. The statement fits her position and responsibilities.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article content and the Wikidata entity’s profile.
